titleStmt.title: The mournful subjects or, The whole nations lamentation, from the highest to the lowest: who did, with brinish tears, (the true signs of sorrow) bewail the death of their most gracious Soveraign King, Charles the second; who departed this life Feb. 6th. 1684. And was interr'd in Westminster-Abby, in King Henry the Seventh's Chappel, on Saturday night last, being the 14th. day of the said month; to the sollid grief and sorrow of all his loving subjects. To the tune of, Troy Town; or, The Dutchess of Suffolk.

The mournful subjects or, The whole nations lamentation, from the highest to the lowest: who did, with brinish tears, (the true signs of sorrow) bewail the death of their most gracious Soveraign King, Charles the second; who departed this life Feb. 6th. 1684. And was interr'd in Westminster-Abby, in King Henry the Seventh's Chappel, on Saturday night last, being the 14th. day of the said month; to the sollid grief and sorrow of all his loving subjects. To the tune of, Troy Town; or, The Dutchess of Suffolk.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for J. Deacon, in Guilt-surp-street [sic],

notesStmt.note: Verse: "True subjects mourn, [and] well they may ..."
Place and date of publication suggested by Wing.
Reproduction of original in the British Library.
